image.altText: Flight crew load a stretcher into a helicopter on a hospital flight pad.

items.synopsis: Rangers say a woman has suffered bites to the lower half of her body after dingoes followed her into the water while she was running along a beach at K'gari (Fraser Island).

title.children: Jogger flown to hospital after being attacked by four dingoes on K'gari in 'very traumatic ordeal'

image.altText: A white man with no hair, dressed in a suit, sits behind a microphone with a concerned expression.

items.synopsis: The executives of one of Australia's leading consultancy firms are criticised for their unwillingness to share information and how they handle complaints of misconduct.

title.children: Deloitte CEO admits he should not be paid seven times more than PM during Senate grilling

image.altText: A couple stand together by a railing on a boat and smile

items.synopsis: The criminal trial into the Whakaari White Island disaster has heard evidence from an Australian survivor who lost both his parents and his only sister in the 2019 eruption.

title.children: 'It still bothers me': Court hears of moment Whakaari survivor was separated from family

image.altText: Police officers huddle around the car on the Logan Motorway.

items.synopsis: Raghe Mohamed Abdi was shot and killed by police on the Logan Motorway, after he lunged at them with a knife. Later that day, the bodies of Maurice and Zoe Antill were found in the backyard of their Parkinson home, with police alleging Mr Abdi had stabbed them to death the night before.

title.children: Inquest into elderly couple's stabbing murders and police shooting of 22-year-old suspect begins

image.altText: Flu vaccination

items.synopsis: Most of the children in hospital were diagnosed with influenza B and only one had been vaccinated.

title.children: Queenslanders to get free flu jabs after child dies with influenza B

image.altText: Images of six people in a digital collage on shapes that appear to form buildings. There are two cranes on top of these shapes.

items.synopsis: For years, Dyldam's string of company collapses has anguished apartment buyers, angered subcontractors, and frustrated liquidators.

title.children: The family empire behind a succession of company collapses, defective buildings and unpaid tradies

image.altText: A with a serious expression wears a dark tracksuit, a chain around his neck, and sunglasses on his head.

items.synopsis: A Gippsland man who broke into a family's home carrying an imitation firearm will be released from prison after a judge said he showed "immediate remorse".

title.children: Armed robber apologises, pays back money and asks for lift home after seeing victim at pokies

image.altText: A barge floats next to a long double-span bridge which curves back and forth over a grey body of water.

items.synopsis: Crimea's Russian-installed governor said an "emergency" situation had occurred near the 145th pillar of the bridge, which links the Crimean peninsula to the Russian mainland.

title.children: Blasts reported on bridge between Russia and Crimea, authorities say child injured in 'emergency situation'

image.altText: Silhouette of an Australian solder in Afghanistan.

items.synopsis: Two years after the Royal Commission into Defence and Veteran Suicide was formed, one of the commissioners tells the opening hearing in Adelaide that key themes to have emerged so far include a "terrible ADF culture" and "bullying, harassment, and abuses of power".

title.children: 'Terrible culture' and 'bullying' within ADF among key themes confronted by royal commission

image.altText: Police cars and police in riot gear on a street

items.synopsis: Police believe the 29-year-old man died from a self-inflicted gunshot wound after they tried to negotiate with him from about midday on Sunday.

title.children: Man dies from gunshot wound after 21-hour siege with NSW police

image.altText: People stand around a large object on a beach

items.synopsis: The object, which washed up at Green Head — 250km north of Perth — is being treated as hazardous until its origins can be established.

title.children: Police guard mysterious item found on remote WA beach

image.altText: A colourful photo of Orange city in the foreground and a mountain in the background.

items.synopsis: The landmark mountain near Orange in NSW — where First Nations people have been gathering for thousands of years — will now be known as Gaanha Bula-Mount Canobolas.

title.children: Mount Canobolas, known to the Wiradjuri as Gaanha Bula or 'two shoulders', is officially renamed

image.altText: A woman crouches next to a campfire on a beach at sunset

items.synopsis: Australians have a reputation for being a sociable bunch, but we're spending more time alone than ever before. Experts say social media, living alone and a fashion for being busy is driving the trend.

title.children: 'Being lonely is like being hungry or thirsty': Why aren't Australians socialising like they used to?

image.altText: A black and white cut-out photo of Wendie Renard kicking a soccerball, against a pale orange background

items.synopsis: More than 700 of the world's best football players will take to stadium pitches all over Australia when FIFA 2023 kicks off this week. The ABC has crunched the data — these are the stars and breakthrough talents you should be looking out for.

title.children: You may not have heard of Wendie Renard, but the 189cm defender could turn out to be the star of the World Cup

image.altText: Two police officers talk to each other behind a car, outside a house where a siege is unfolding.

items.synopsis: A man has been charged with more than a dozen offences after an alleged siege in Brisbane on Sunday.

title.children: Man charged with more than a dozen offences after alleged siege in inner-Brisbane suburb

image.altText: The sign outside Darwin Local Court. Picture taken June 22, 2021.

items.synopsis: A Darwin woman has pleaded guilty to high range drink driving and careless driving after colliding into a traffic sign on Boxing Day last year.

title.children: Judge berates driver who blacked out and drove five times over the alcohol limit

image.altText: the PWC sign inside its lobby, with a woman in a red jacket walking by

items.synopsis: Until now, the big four accounting firms had built themselves an aura of credibility and trust in government and corporate Australia, writes Adele Ferguson.

title.children: How four companies infiltrated governments and took home $10 billion

image.altText: Long shot of an older indigenous man standing in tall grass near a statue.

items.synopsis: The Yindjibarndi Aboriginal Corporation has fought for years for compensation from iron ore mines in the Pilbara, but may soon be producing renewable energy to sell to those same companies.

title.children: Multi-billion-dollar renewables project earmarked for Yindjibarndi native title land

image.altText: Rescuers wade waist-deep in floodwaters in front of a submerged bus.

items.synopsis: Days of torrential rain leaves dozens dead and at least nine missing, many of whom were trapped in a flooded tunnel in the central city of Cheongju.

title.children: South Korean president orders all-out effort as flood death toll rises to 40

image.altText: Gouldian finches stand on a branch.

items.synopsis: While numbers of this tiny endangered bird are on the rise elsewhere, Gouldian finches are nowhere to be seen in this Kimberley environmental buffer designed to protect them.

title.children: Why have these tiny, colourful Gouldian finches vanished from a Kimberley refuge?

image.altText: Spain's Carlos Alcaraz celebrates with the trophy after winning his final match against Serbia's Novak Djokovic.

items.synopsis: Carlos Alcaraz defeats Novak Djokovic to win Wimbledon in a five-set epic that saw a 26-minute service game, superb tennis and Djokovic destroying a racquet on the net post.

title.children: Carlos Alcaraz won his first Wimbledon title and left Novak Djokovic fuming as a 45-match winning streak was snapped

image.altText: A person with short hair leans against a sandstone wall and smiles.

items.synopsis: Tasmania is the first state to officially recognise those who identify as asexual, adding the A to the LGBTIQ+ initialism on all government documents.

title.children: First Australian state officially adds 'A' to recognised LGBTIQ+ term

image.altText: Margot Robbie dressed as Barbie wearing a black and white striped swimsuit, white sunglasses, miniature children holding dolls

items.synopsis: Barbie's longevity may come down to the fact that she has not remained the same, adapting to appeal to changing societal values.

title.children: Barbie began life as a blonde. Her evolution could be the key to her success

image.altText: Image of pink patties on a conveyer belt.

items.synopsis: Alternative protein producers in Australia are navigating a period of reset following a dramatic year of stock market price falls for major meat substitute companies.

title.children: Plant-based food industry makes leap forward as scientists discover missing 'fatty' meat flavour

image.altText: The ASX close to steady in early trade as seen on the exchange's board at its Sydney office

items.synopsis: The ASX is following Wall Street's subdued lead from Friday with flat trade, while the Senate continues to probe the consulting industry. Follow the day's events and insights from our business reporters on the ABC News live markets blog.

title.children: 'Bastardisation' of consulting partnerships 'warrants' royal commission, ASX trades flat

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: This is definitely my favourite phrase to emerge from today's Senate hearings into the big four accounting/consulting firms. Professor Brendan Lyon, formerly a partner at KPMG between 2018-2021, has coined it to describe the way those firms act as intellectual guns for higher for both governments and the corporate sector. "Decision-based evidence-making" is where clients seek to use the reputation of those big four firms to imply a decision they want to take is backed by rigorous evidence, even when it isn't. Professor Lyon said he experienced this when working on a transport project for the NSW government. He said when he refused to change an assessment which contradicted NSW Treasury and another KPMG team working for them, he was pushed out. "If you speak out against the direction, you're very quickly segregated," he observed.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: 'Decision-based evidence-making'

children.content: This is definitely my favourite phrase to emerge from today's Senate hearings into the big four accounting/consulting firms.
Professor Brendan Lyon, formerly a partner at KPMG between 2018-2021, has coined it to describe the way those firms act as intellectual guns for higher for both governments and the corporate sector.
"Decision-based evidence-making" is where clients seek to use the reputation of those big four firms to imply a decision they want to take is backed by rigorous evidence, even when it isn't.

Professor Lyon said he experienced this when working on a transport project for the NSW government. He said when he refused to change an assessment which contradicted NSW Treasury and another KPMG team working for them, he was pushed out.
"If you speak out against the direction, you're very quickly segregated," he observed.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Brendan Lyon will probably not be getting many dinner party invites from his former colleagues at KPMG, or any of the three other big accounting/consultancy firms. When discussing firms' normal claim of "a few bad apples" when they are are accused of wrongdoing, Professor Lyon flipped that analogy. "I think there's four big rotten barrels with some good apples sitting within," he told the Senate. "I think that's one of the reasons that a royal commission is probably warranted." Professor Lyon said "the taxpayer has got a lot to worry about" from much of the advice these firms provide governments, while "all of us have got a lot to worry about" if the kind of practices he observed are replicated in the way these firms audit their private sector clients.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: 'Four big rotten barrels with some good apples', royal commission 'warranted'

children.content: Brendan Lyon
will probably not be getting many dinner party invites from his former colleagues at KPMG, or any of the three other big accounting/consultancy firms.
When discussing firms' normal claim of "a few bad apples" when they are are accused of wrongdoing, Professor Lyon flipped that analogy.
"I think there's four big rotten barrels with some good apples sitting within," he told the Senate.
"I think that's one of the reasons that a royal commission is probably warranted."

Professor Lyon said "the taxpayer has got a lot to worry about" from much of the advice these firms provide governments, while "all of us have got a lot to worry about" if the kind of practices he observed are replicated in the way these firms audit their private sector clients.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Brendan Lyon was a partner at KPMG between 2018-2021, following a decade as chief executive of Infrastructure Partnerships Australia. He is now a professor of practice at the University of Wollongong's faculty of business and law. Professor Lyons says: "The big four have enjoyed a compliant regulator … that has allowed the bastardisation of the partnership model." He said the big four accounting/consulting firms and their partners enjoyed a business model that was "risk free, tax free and consequence free". Professor Lyon pointed out that, as partnerships, the firms paid no company tax (partners and staff pay income tax on their earnings — at least in theory), no state payroll tax and are not required to publicly publish audited financial statements. But he said that, unlike other partnerships, there is a $10 million cap on liability for the accounting firms, which is then insured. "The big four sit in every corporate boardroom across Australia but face no oversight," he said. Professor Lyon said he never saw a financial statement during his time as a partner at KPMG. He said that most partners do not fear potential financial or professional consequences from any misconduct.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Former KPMG partner Brendan Lyon drops a bomb on the accounting industry

children.content: Brendan Lyon was a partner at KPMG between 2018-2021, following a decade as chief executive of Infrastructure Partnerships Australia.
He is now a professor of practice at the University of Wollongong's faculty of business and law.
Professor Lyons says: "The big four have enjoyed a compliant regulator … that has allowed the bastardisation of the partnership model."
He said the big four accounting/consulting firms and their partners enjoyed a business model that was "risk free, tax free and consequence free".

Professor Lyon pointed out that, as partnerships, the firms paid no company tax (partners and staff pay income tax on their earnings — at least in theory), no state payroll tax and are not required to publicly publish audited financial statements.
But he said that, unlike other partnerships, there is a $10 million cap on liability for the accounting firms, which is then insured.
"The big four sit in every corporate boardroom across Australia but face no oversight," he said.
Professor Lyon said he never saw a financial statement during his time as a partner at KPMG.
He said that most partners do not fear potential financial or professional consequences from any misconduct.

image.altText: Image of fire on the deck of Antarctic supply ship Everest.

items.synopsis: The crew of an Australian-leased resupply vessel were "unsure if they (would) have to abandon ship" when large flames began erupting from its engine room in the Southern Ocean two years ago, Freedom of Information documents reveal.

title.children: 'Unsure if they will have to abandon ship': New details reveal danger of Antarctic ship fire

image.altText: Airport security screens passengers.

items.synopsis: Some countries no longer require you to remove your shoes when passing through security — but taking out your laptop is still mostly required, writes Doug Drury.

title.children: Why you have to take out your laptop — and other fascinating facts about airport security

image.altText: David Warner looks behind him

items.synopsis: The case for and against David Warner retaining his opener spot as Australia faces tough selection choices ahead of the fourth Ashes Test at Old Trafford.

title.children: David Warner poses a problem at the top of the batting order, but what other options are there?

image.altText: A group of walkers stand in a grassy campsite with their arms around each other, smiling.

items.synopsis: News Breakfast co-host Lisa Millar swapped the studio for a 250-kilometre walk over Victoria's coastline, forest and riverbanks — from Portland to Nelson on the South Australian border — for an episode of ABC TV's Back Roads.

title.children: Lifting the veil on one of Australia's most beautiful, but least known, long walks

image.altText: A grainy photograph of a young woman holding up a yellow soccer shirt with AUSTRALIA on the back

items.synopsis: Sandra Brentnall was just 17 when she scored Australia's first international goal in women's soccer, despite wearing boots that were two sizes too big.

title.children: Sandra scored Australia's first international goal in women's soccer wearing boots stuffed with newspaper
